attachments.caption: Construction of main roof of the Boston Garden

element_texts.text: Construction of main roof of the Boston Garden
1 photographic print : gelatin silver ; 8 x 10 in.

Newspaper caption on verso reads, "The first of the seven roof trusses supporting the main roof of the new North Station Coliseum was raised into position today.  These trusses are the largest of their kind in this section of the country.  They span 40 feet more than the trusses of the Boston Arena and each one carries twice as much roof area."

page_blocks.text:
The Boston Garden opened in 1928 above bustling North Station. Considered one of the premier indoor venues of its time, the Garden attracted professional sports franchises—most notably Bruins hockey and Celtics basketball—as well as a wide variety of shows, sporting contests, and rallies.

The Garden’s location above a rail station reflected the common practice at the time of locating arenas in urban centers near public transportation. With seats for roughly 15,000 fans, the stadium boasted over twice the capacity of the existing Boston Arena across town.

attachments.caption:
CONSTRUCTION OF MAIN ROOF OF THE BOSTON GARDEN, 1928. Boston Herald-Traveler Photo Morgue, BPL Print Department. 

The Boston Garden opened on November 17, 1928, over the railways of North Station at Causeway Street. At center, the framing for two levels of seating begins to take shape.

element_texts.text: Construction of main roof of the Boston Garden
1 photographic print : gelatin silver ; 8 x 10 in.

Newspaper caption on verso reads, "The first of the seven roof trusses supporting the main roof of the new North Station Coliseum was raised into position today.  These trusses are the largest of their kind in this section of the country.  They span 40 feet more than the trusses of the Boston Arena and each one carries twice as much roof area."

attachments.caption:
AERIAL VIEW, NORTH STATION, ca. 1935. BPL Fine Arts Department. 

This aerial view shows the tracks of the Boston and Maine railroad line at left and Causeway Street at right.

element_texts.text: 1 photographic print on mount : gelatin silver ; 8 x 10 in., on mount 11 x 14 in.
Aerial photograph showing roof and facade of the Boston Garden.  The Hotel Manger is to the left of the Garden.  Facade faces on Causeway Street.  Boston and Maine trackage visible to left of photo.

page_blocks.text: Opened in 1915, Braves Field was designed by the same firm that had built Fenway Park three years earlier. Constructed on the site of a former golf course in Allston, Massachusetts, the stadium was the largest baseball park built at that time, with a capacity of more than 46,000 fans.

attachments.caption:
AERIAL VIEW OF BRAVES FIELD, 1933. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department.

The enormous new ballpark was built on the banks of the Charles River in Allston next to the Boston & Albany train yards.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
INFIELD AT BRAVES FIELD, 1930. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

The stands were the largest ever constructed at the time and designed so that every seat would have a good view of the play on the field.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
View of field and crowd in grandstand behind home plate at Braves Field.
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
REMARKABLE CROWD AT BRAVES' NEW FIELD IN ALLSTON, 1915. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Braves Field welcomed over 46,000 fans for Opening Day on August 18, 1915.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Remarkable crowd at Braves' new field in Allston
Crowd in third base grandstand at newly constructed Braves Field.
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
CROWD AFTER GAME AT BRAVES FIELD, ca. 1935. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Braves Field opened to much optimism and fanfare, with the Boston Globe declaring, “There is not another like it anywhere.”

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Crowd after game at Braves Field
Street scene of crowd departing Braves Field after game.
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption: Kenmore Square, Fenway Park Area, 1950-59

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Fenway Park is in the center of the image.  The field is lined for football.

page_blocks.text:
A century ago, one of the most storied venues in sports history opened its gates, welcoming fans to Fenway Park. The baseball stadium that John Updike famously called “a lyric little bandbox” in 1960 has evolved since its first season in 1912, but its allure has persisted for generations of ever-faithful fans.

The oldest major league stadium still in use, Fenway Park has undergone a series of major renovations during the past century, yet stepping through its gates today still feels like stepping back in time.

attachments.caption:
KENMORE SQUARE, FENWAY PARK AREA, 1950-59. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Fenway Park's unique layout reflects the asymmetrical parcel upon which it was built.This aerial shot shows the park’s shortened left field, the Fenway/Kenmore neighborhood, and the Charles River.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Fenway Park is in the center of the image.  The field is lined for football.

attachments.caption:
CROWD RINGS FIELD, OPENING DAY AT FENWAY, 1934. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Although thousands of seats have been added to the park in recent years, Fenway’s capacity was larger in its early days, when fans were allowed to sit and stand along the warning track.

element_texts.text: Copyright   Leslie Jones; This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Crowd rings field, opening day at Fenway
Overflow crowd sitting on field in front of centerfield grandstand area at Fenway Park.
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
FENWAY PARK FIRE, 1934. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Much of Fenway Park had to be rebuilt following a devastating fire that reached nearly every part of the ballpark in January 1934.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Fire trucks battling the off-season fire in left field corner grandstand of Fenway Park.
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
BAND ON FIELD, OPENING DAY AT FENWAY, 1963. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department.  

A band plays on Opening Day in 1963, with the Prudential Tower under construction in the distance. As the city of Boston has changed around it, Fenway Park has endured.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Band on field, Opening Day at Fenway
Harvard University Band performs in shallow centerfield at Fenway Park.  Prudential Building under construction in background.

page_blocks.text:
Boston fans have been captivated by professional sports ever since major league baseball first took the field at South End Grounds in 1871. While our legendary teams and athletes have long composed the dramatic narratives, these home venues—veritable “temples” of sport—have served as their iconic center stages.

Boston Sports Temples celebrates the rich histories of Boston’s professional stadiums and arenas. Some, like Fenway Park, still welcome fans today. Others were demolished decades ago, leaving only hints of their former glory amid the urban landscape. This exhibition welcomes modern fans through the gates of venues both famous and forgotten: the various home fields—and courts and tracks and ice—of Boston’s most beloved franchises and hosts to a century of public events, concerts, and gatherings.

Featuring historical photographs from the Boston Public Library’s extensive archives, Boston Sports Temples draws from thousands of negatives and prints dating from the early twentieth century through the 1960s. 

The images capture the unique character of Boston’s historic sports venues, memorable moments, and the communities of athletes, fans, and staff who have come together within their walls. Together, these vintage materials provide an invaluable window into the past and a nostalgic look back at our city, our deep sporting traditions, and generations of passionate fandom.

attachments.caption: Horse Race, ca. 1936

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

page_blocks.text:
During the Great Depression in the 1930s, cash-strapped state governments looked for new means to increase their treasuries during hard times. In 1934, Massachusetts legalized pari-mutuel racing and, within a year, the Eastern Racing Association—led by Boston Bruins founder and president Charles F. Adams—constructed Suffolk Downs, the state’s first thoroughbred racing track. 

Built on 200 acres of mudflats in East Boston, Suffolk Downs opened its doors in July 1935, making front page news throughout the region. Construction had been completed in only 62 days at a cost of $2,000,000.  The racetrack included America’s first concrete grandstand; featuring 16,000 seats, it was the largest grandstand in the nation.

attachments.caption:
HORSE RACE, ca. 1936. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department

Over 35,000 visitors attended the opening day races on July 10, 1935.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
AIRPLANE VIEW OF SUFFOLK DOWNS, 1935. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

During the 44-day inaugural racing season, parking lots were packed and the Boston & Maine Railroad began running a non-stop Suffolk Special from North Station.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Aerial view of the clubhouse and large crowd at Suffolk Downs, East Boston.

attachments.caption:
HORSE RACING, ca. 1939. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department.  

In its first year, Suffolk Downs enjoyed an average daily attendance of nearly 15,000 fans.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
1 negative : film, black & white ; 3 1/8 x 4 1/4 in.

attachments.caption:
UNIDENTIFIED COUPLE AT SUFFOLK DOWNS, 1936. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Horse racing was one of the most popular spectator sports in New England from the 1930s to the 1960s. Well dressed patrons filled the VIP sections of the clubhouse and rooftop balconies.

element_texts.text: Copyright   Leslie Jones.; This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Unidentified couple at Suffolk Downs - see program
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

page_blocks.text:
Even with the new stadium, Braves game attendance lagged far behind that of Boston's perenially popular American League team, the Red Sox. However, the Braves did boast a loyal corps of fans who supported the team, season after season.

To boost ticket sales, publicity director Billy Sullivan—future owner of the Patriots professional football team—introduced a variety of new marketing strategies, including night baseball games featuring players wearing special satin uniforms to increase visibility, fan appreciation days, and the first color highlight films.

attachments.caption:
SPECTATORS, ca.1935. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Major League Baseball’s first commissioner, Kenesaw Mountain Landis, leans on the railing at Braves Field, watching the action. Red Sox owner Tom Yawkey is seated to Landis’s left in the background.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Braves Field (Boston, Mass.); Yawkey, Thomas A., 1903-1976; Landis, Kenesaw Mountain, 1866-1944
Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw Landis leaning on the railing at Braves Field with Red Sox owner Tom Yawkey seated in the background.
1 negative : film, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
BEES PLAYERS WITH THEIR WIVES AT BRAVES FIELD, 1939. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department.  

Boston Bees players Ralph Hodgin (sitting on wall), Buddy Hassett, and Max West pose with a group of players’ wives along the third base railing.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Bees players with their wives at Braves Field
Boston Braves (Baseball team); Braves Field (Boston, Mass.)
(l to r:) Boston Bees players Ralph Hodgin (sitting on wall between women), Buddy Hassett, Max West, and unknown surrounded by a group of women along the third base railing at Braves Field.
1 negative : film, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
LOLLY HOPKINS AT BRAVES FIELD, 1940. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department.  

Lillian (Lolly) Hopkins, holding her trademark megaphone, was a faithful supporter of both the Boston Braves and the Boston Red Sox. Hopkins is pictured here with her vocal group of female Braves fans known as the Lolly Pops.

element_texts.text: 1 photographic print : gelatin silver ; 6 3/8 x 7 in.
Hopkins, far right holding megaphone, was the founding member of a group of female Boston Braves fans called the LollyPops.
This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.

attachments.caption:
SCORECARD VENDOR, BRAVES FIELD, ca. 1945. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

The Braves publicity department introduced a number of innovative new offerings to lure fans, including the first full-color scorecard distributed by vendors such as this engaging fellow.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
1 negative : film, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

page_blocks.text:
Boston’s first professional baseball team was not the storied Boston Red Sox but a National League club that became known as the Boston Braves. A powerhouse team throughout the late 1800s, the Braves won the 1914 World Series, which led to renewed surge of fan interest and the building of the enormous new Braves Field.  

The Braves boasted many notable players, but the team struggled throughout most of their thirty-seven years at Braves Field, both on the field and financially.

attachments.caption: BRAVES, 1933. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Baseball players; Baseball managers; Coaches (Athletics); Stadiums

(top row, l to r:) Boston Braves outfielder Wally Berger, Boston Braves catcher Shanty Hogan, Boston Braves pitcher Ed Brandt, Boston Braves pitcher Ed Fallenstein, Boston Braves coach Hank Gowdy. (bottom row, l to r:) Boston Braves second baseman Rabbit Maranville, Boston Braves outfielder Red Worthington, Boston Braves manager Bill McKechnie, Boston Braves pitcher Bob Brown.
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
BRAVES AT HARVARD CAGE, 1935. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

To boost the team’s flagging financial fortunes, owner Emil Fuchs recruited an aging George “Babe” Ruth to the Braves in 1935.  Ruth lasted only two months with the Boston Braves in 1935 before his retirement as a player.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
(r to l:) Boston Braves outfielder Babe Ruth, Boston Braves outfielder Tommy Thompson, unidentified Boston Braves players.
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
PLAY AT THE PLATE, BEES VS. CARDINALS, 1937. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

From 1936 to 1941, the owners changed the name of the team to the Boston Bees and Braves Field was known as “The Bee Hive.”

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Play at the plate, Bees vs. Cardinals
Baseball players; Baseball umpires; Baseball; Stadiums
Boston Braves (Baseball team); St. Louis Cardinals (Baseball team); Braves Field (Boston, Mass.)
Unknown St. Louis Cardinal slides across home plate as Boston Bees catcher Al Spohrer applies the tag in front of umpire Dolly Stark at Braves Field.
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
STARTING LINE UP OF THE BRAVES IN DUGOUT, 1951. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department.

In April 1950, Sam Jethroe (second from left) premiered with the Braves; he was Boston’s first black professional player in any team sport. In 1951, Jethroe was joined by Luis Márquez (fourth from right), a Puerto Rican and the first black player to sign with the New York Yankees.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Starting line up of the Braves in dugout
Boston Braves (Baseball team); Braves Field (Boston, Mass.); Jethroe, Sam, 1918-2001

Boston Braves starting lineup. (l to r:) Roy Hartsfield, Sam Jethroe, Earl Torgeson, Bob Elliott, Sid Gordon, Luis Marquez, Walker Cooper, Johnny Logan, and Vern Bickford on the dugout steps at Braves Field.
1 negative : film, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

page_blocks.text:
During the outstanding 1948 season, Braves Field hosted the first and only World Series for the home team. The city of Boston came very close to hosting a “subway series” that year; across town, the Red Sox lost a heartbreaking one-game playoff to the Cleveland Indians for the American League title. 

Cleveland would go on to win the World Series championship over the Braves in six games.

attachments.caption:
MANAGER BILLY SOUTHWORTH AUTOGRAPHING BALLS AT BRAVES FIELD, ca. 1949. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Former Braves centerfielder Billy Southworth returned to manage the team in 1946 and led the Braves during their extraordinary 1948 season.

element_texts.text: Copyright   Leslie Jones; This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Manager Billy Southworth autographing balls at Braves field
Boston Braves (Baseball team); Braves Field (Boston, Mass.)
Boston Braves Manager Billy Southworth autographing boxes of baseballs in the clubhouse at Braves Field.
1 negative : film, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
BOSTON BRAVES—J. SAIN & W. SPAHN,  ca. 1948. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

The extraordinary pitching duo of right-hander Johnny Sain and lefty Warren Spahn inspired Boston Post sports editor Gerald V. Hern to write a poem later popularized as “Spahn and Sain and Pray for Rain.”

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Boston Braves - J. Sain & W. Spahn
Boston Braves (Baseball team); Braves Field (Boston, Mass.); Spahn, Warren, 1921-2003
(l to r:) Boston Braves pitchers Johnny Sain and Warren Spahn in dugout at Braves Field.
1 negative : film, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
CUBS TRY TO SCORE VS. BRAVES, ca. 1948. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department.

Interest in the Boston Braves surged with their incredible 1948 season, which culminated in the National League championship and the team’s first appearance in a World Series in 34 years.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Cubs try to score vs. Braves
Boston Braves (Baseball team); Chicago Cubs (Baseball team); Braves Field (Boston, Mass.)

Chicago Cub Gene Mauch (#33) slides toward home plate in front of Boston Braves catcher Bill Salkeld (#15) and home plate umpire Lee Ballanfant as Cubs players Peanuts Lowrey and one other unknown Cub look on at Braves Field.
1 negative : film, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
RAISING THE BRAVES NATIONAL LEAGUE PENNANT AT BRAVES FIELD, 1949. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

 Officials pose with 1948 National League pennant prior to Marines raising the banner at Braves Field on Opening Day in 1949.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Raising the Braves National League pennant at Braves Field
Boston Braves (Baseball team); Braves Field (Boston, Mass.); Frick, Ford C.

Officials pose with 1948 National League pennant prior to Marines raising the banner at Braves Field on Opening Day 1949. (l to r, on left of pennant) Braves co-owner Guido Rugo, general manager John Quinn, owner Joe Maney, (on right of pennant) owner Lou Perini, and National League president Ford Frick. Player representative Tommy Holmes and manager Billy Southworth are visible on right behind pennant.
1 negative : film, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

page_blocks.text:
Attendance at Boston Braves games dwindled to a mere 281,000 in 1952; only two games during the 1952 season saw 10,000 or more fans in the nearly empty stands. Still, fans and players alike were shocked when the ownership suddenly sold the Braves to Milwaukee during spring training in Florida in 1953. 

The team never returned to Boston, and Braves Field was sold to Boston University and renamed. In 1955, a major portion of the field was torn down to make space for dormitories.

attachments.caption:
BRAVES AND OPPONENTS LINE UP ON FIELD BEFORE THE GAME, 1952. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

The Boston Braves and Brooklyn Dodgers line up for the playing of the national anthem on Opening Day of their final season at Braves Field.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Braves and opponents line up on field before the game
Boston Braves (Baseball team); Brooklyn Dodgers (Baseball team); Braves Field (Boston, Mass.)

Boston Braves (on third base line) and Brooklyn Dodgers (on first base line) line up for the playing of the national anthem by a military honor guard on Opening Day of the 1952 season at Braves Field.
1 negative : film, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
BRAVES MASCOT WITH DIGNITARIES, ca. 1948. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Lou Perini (second from left) owned the Boston Braves from 1944 through the 1952 season. While Perini was vilified in some circles for selling the team to Milwaukee, Wisconsin, his most enduring legacy is the creation of the world-renowned Jimmy Fund charity in 1947, which continues to raise millions of dollars annually for cancer research.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Boston Braves (Baseball team); Braves Field (Boston, Mass.)
Boston Braves Indian chief mascot with Braves owner Lou Perini (second from left in top coat) and other dignitaries throwing out the ceremonial first pitch on Opening Day at Braves Field.
1 negative : film, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
MILWAUKEE BRAVES, 1953. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Former Boston teammates Warren Spahn, Vern Bickford, and Sibby Sisti are pictured in their new uniforms as Milwaukee Braves.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Milwaukee Braves (Baseball team); Braves Field (Boston, Mass.); Spahn, Warren, 1921-2003
(l to r:) Milwaukee Braves Warren Spahn, Vern Bickford, and Sibby Sisti on the dugout steps at Braves Field.
1 negative : film, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
TEARING DOWN BRAVES FIELD FOR B.U. FIELD, 1955. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Only a few portions of the old Braves Field, most notably the right field grandstands, remain as part of Boston University’s Nickerson Field.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Tearing down Braves Field for B.U. field
View of partially demolished facade from inside Braves Field concourse.
1 negative : film, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

page_blocks.text:
While exciting plays on the baseball diamond continue to command the most attention at Fenway Park, quieter faces and spaces behind the scenes are equally significant. 

Groundskeepers, locker room attendants, trainers, gatecheckers, and thousands more staff and crew over the years have long contributed to the park's success.

attachments.caption:
RED SOX TRAINER BITS BIERHALTER STOKES UP THE HOT STOVE IN CLUBHOUSE AT FENWAY, ca. 1928. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Wielding a shovel, a Red Sox trainer stokes the stove in the Red Sox clubhouse at Fenway Park while players gather around him.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Red Sox trainer Bits Bierhalter, stokes up the hot stove in clubhouse at Fenway
Coaches (Athletics); Baseball players; Locker rooms; Stoves
Boston Red Sox (Baseball team); Fenway Park (Boston, Mass.)
Red Sox trainer Bits Bierhalter (with shovel) stokes up the stove in the Red Sox locker room while several players, including pitcher Danny MacFayden (wearing glasses), look on.
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption: RED SOX PLAYERS IN CLUBHOUSE. L-R: ED “BULL” DURHAM, WILCY MOORE, BOB KLINE AND PAUL IVY ANDREWS, 1932. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department.

element_texts.text: Copyright   Leslie Jones.; This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Red Sox players in clubhouse. L-R:  Ed Bull Durham, Wiley Moore, Bob Kline and Paul Ivy Andrews
Red Sox players in clubhouse.  left to right:  Ed "Bull" Durham, Wiley Moore, Bob Kline and Paul Ivy Andrews.

attachments.caption:
GATEMAN AT FENWAY, ca. 1950. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Gateman no. 3, unmistakable in his hat and dressed for the occasion, welcomes fans at one of Fenway’s west entrances. He sits above what modern fans know as “Yawkey Way”—named for the Red Sox owner from 1933-76.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Unknown elderly gateman at his post at Fenway Park.
1 negative : film, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption: TWO MEN INSPECT THE GROUNDS NEAR LEFT FIELD SCOREBOARD IN FENWAY, 1935. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department.

element_texts.text: Copyright   Leslie Jones.; This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Inspecting the grounds in front of Fenway scoreboard
Two men in suits examine spot on field in front of the scoreboard on the left field wall at Fenway Park.

page_blocks.text:
Built on mudflats at a cost of $650,000, Fenway Park was constructed in 1912 for the new American League team in town, the Boston Red Sox.  

One of the smallest parks in Major League Baseball, Fenway is beloved by Sox players and fans—if not opposing teams—for its quirky architectural features, storied past, and generations of poignant memories captured within its confines.

attachments.caption:
CLOSE PLAY AT FIRST, FENWAY PARK, 1934. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department

The Green Monster, Fenway's left field wall, remains one of the most famous features in any professional sports venue. It was constructed from concrete, covered in tin, and clad in green-painted wood.

element_texts.text: Copyright © Leslie Jones.; This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Close play at first, Fenway Park
Boston Red Sox (Baseball team); New York Yankees (Baseball team); Fenway Park (Boston, Mass.)
Unknown Boston Red Sox pitcher races to cover first base and just beats unknown New York Yankee base runner to the bag for the out at Fenway Park.
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
RED SOX OUTFIELDER LEON CULBERSON LEAPS IN FRONT OF SCOREBOARD AT FENWAY PARK, 1943. Boston Herald-Traveler Photo Morgue, BPL Print Department. 

Fenway Park's manually-operated scoreboard, added in 1934, is the last of its kind in the major leagues.

element_texts.text: Red Sox outfielder Leon Culberson leaps in front of scoreboard at Fenway Park

Newspaper caption on verso reads, "Culberson Knows How to Play His Hand and the former pride of Louisville shows how to prevent a grand slam during the practice session at Fenway Park.  Leon is his first name and this is his first view of Boston and Fenway Park, since he joined the Hose on the road."
1 photographic print : gelatin silver ; 7 x 9 in.

attachments.caption:
BIG BASEBALL CROWD AT FENWAY PARK, 1924. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department.  

When the ballpark first opened, it could hold 35,000 spectators in the stands and along the edge of the field.

element_texts.text: Copyright © Leslie Jones.; This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Big crowd to see the Red Sox, vendor in white jacket in upper center.
1 photographic print : gelatin silver ; 8 x 10 in.

attachments.caption:
LIGHTS AT FENWAY PARK ON AT 4:30 BECAUSE OF SMOKE FROM FOREST FIRES IN CANADA, 1950. Boston Herald-Traveler Photo Morgue, BPL Print Department.

The Red Sox were the fourteenth out of sixteen teams in the major leagues to hold night games. It was not until 1947 that lights regularly illuminated the park.

element_texts.text: Lights at Fenway Park on at 4:30 because of smoke from forest fires in Canada
1 photographic print : gelatin silver ; 7 x 9 in.
Fenway Park looked like this yesterday when the lights turned on at 4:30 p.m. during the Red Sox-Washington double header.  Darkness was caused by smoke from Canadian forest fires.

page_blocks.text:
Generations of passionate Red Sox fans have filled Fenway's stands night after night, season after season, cheering on their beloved team. 

While the earliest fans at Fenway Park enjoyed a quick succession of World Series championships in 1912, 1915, 1916, and 1918, the legions of loyal supporters born after 1918 waited for nearly a lifetime until they were rewarded with championships in 2004 and 2007.

attachments.caption: TWO LADIES AT TICKET WINDOW, FENWAY PARK, ca. 1945. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department

element_texts.text: Copyright   Leslie Jones.; This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Two ladies at ticket window, Fenway Park
Women purchasing tickets from ticket agent in Fenway ticket office.

attachments.caption:
CARDINAL CUSHING WITH NUN AT BASEBALL GAME, 1950. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Cardinal Richard Cushing cheers on the home team.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Cardinal Cushing with nun at baseball game
Cardinal Richard Cushing sits with sunglass wearing nun in stands at Fenway Park.

attachments.caption:
KIDS CROWDING OUTSIDE THE BLEACHERS ENTRANCE ON OPENING DAY AT FENWAY, 1956. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department.

A group of school children, some carrying sack lunches, gather outside of the bleacher section at Fenway Park to celebrate Opening Day.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Kids crowding outside the bleachers entrance on Opening Day at Fenway
Group of young school kids, some with their sack lunches, outside the bleacher section at Fenway Park.
1 negative : film, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
MEDAL OF HONOR WINNER U.S. ARMY SERGEANT CHARLES A. MACGILLIVARY AND CONGRESSMAN JOHN F. KENNEDY AT FENWAY PARK, ca. 1945. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

John F. Kennedy’s grandfather, Mayor John Fitzgerald, was a member of the Royal Rooters and threw out the ceremonial first pitch at Fenway Park’s dedication in 1912. Kennedy is pictured here at the ballpark early in his political career.

element_texts.text: Medal of Honor winner U.S. Army sergeant Charles A. MacGillivary and congressman John F. Kennedy at Fenway Park, 1940s

page_blocks.text:
Fenway Park has long been home to some of the greatest players of baseball lore. 

While only eight uniform numbers have been formally retired by the Red Sox, the ballpark has served as the playground for scores of the sport's most famous figures during the past century.

attachments.caption:
BABE RUTH AT FENWAY PARK, 1915. Sports Images Collection, BPL Print Department. 

One of baseball’s most legendary players, George “Babe” Ruth played for the Red Sox from 1914 to 1919 before his famous trade to the New York Yankees.

element_texts.text: 1 photographic print : gelatin silver ; 11 x 14 in.
Babe Ruth, Boston Red Sox pitcher, in front of stands at Fenway.

attachments.caption:
RED SOX, 1939. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department

Hall of Famers Jimmie Foxx, Bobby Doerr, and Joe Cronin are pictured with Jim Tabor on the dugout steps.

element_texts.text: Copyright   Leslie Jones.; This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Boston Red Sox (Baseball team); Fenway Park (Boston, Mass.); Foxx, Jimmie; Doerr, Bobby, 1918-; Cronin, Joe, 1906-
(l to r:) Boston Red Sox Jimmie Foxx, Bobby Doerr, Joe Cronin, and Jim Tabor on the dugout steps at Fenway Park. This is the starting infield.
1 negative : film, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
TED WILLIAMS CROSSES THE PLATE AT FENWAY, 1939. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Ted Williams holds the title for the longest home run in Fenway Park at 502 feet, commemorated by a single red seat in the stands.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Ted Williams crosses the plate at Fenway
Ted Williams crosses the plate at Fenway Park and is greeted by a teammate.  The left field wall is visible in background covered with advertisements.

attachments.caption:
RED SOX TEAM AT FENWAY PARK, 1951. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

The lineup of the 1951 Red Sox, positioned here for the National Anthem, contained some of the most famous player numbers in franchise history, four of which are now retired from use and commemorated above the right field grandstand: #1 (Bobby Doerr), #4 (Joe Cronin), #6 (Johnny Pesky), and #9 (Ted Williams).

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Red Sox team at Fenway Park
Baseball players; Baseball managers; Coaches (Athletics); Stadiums
Boston Red Sox (Baseball team); Fenway Park (Boston, Mass.); Williams, Ted, 1918-2002; Doerr, Bobby, 1918-; DiMaggio, Dom; Pesky, Johnny, 1919-

Boston Red Sox players stand for the National Anthem. (l tor:) Manager Steve O'Neill, Coach Eddie Mayo, Coach Paul Schreiber, Al Evans, Chuck Stobbs, Les Moss, Ted Williams, Coach Earle Combs, Walt Dropo, Vern Stephens, Lou Boudreau, Billy Goodman, Bobby Doerr, Bill Evans, Harry Taylor, Dom DiMaggio, Buddy Rosar, Mickey McDermott, unidentified player, Ellis Kinder, Bill Wight, Tom Wright, Ray Scarborough, Fred Hatfield, Walt Masterson, unidentified player, Johnny Pesky, and unidentified player.
1 negative : film, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

page_blocks.text:
The Garden welcomed the Boston Celtics in 1946, when the professional basketball team was imported from its previous home at the Boston Arena across town. 

The Celtics brought the Arena’s parquet floor with them, which had been constructed from wood scraps during a post-war lumber shortage. The floor and its irregularities became a signature feature of the Garden.

attachments.caption:
CELTIC SCORES VS. SYRACUSE AT GARDEN, ca. 1952. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

In this image, Celtic Chuck Cooper leaps over defenders from the Syracuse Nationals, later the Philadelphia 76ers. Cooper was the first African-American drafted by a professional team when the Boston Celtics selected him in 1950.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Celtic scores vs. Syracuse at Garden
Basketball players; Basketball; Sports & recreation facilities
Boston Celtics (Basketball team); Boston Garden (Boston, Mass.)
1 negative : film, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
AUERBACH AND OTHER CELTICS LISTEN TO TOM HEINSOHN, ca. 1956. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Legendary Celtics coach Arnold “Red” Auerbach chats with his players in the Garden locker room. Auerbach built the Celtics into a dynasty, winning 11 NBA Titles in his 13 seasons of coaching the team.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Auerbach and other Celtics listen to Tom Heinsohn
Red Auerbach in locker room at Boston Garden with Celtics players and team officials.

attachments.caption:
COUSY WITH LAYUP FOR CELTICS AT GARDEN VS. KNICKS, ca. 1955. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Bob Cousy (#14) takes a layup shot against the New York Knicks. Cousy’s ball handling talents on six championship Celtics teams earned him a regular introduction at the Garden as “Mr. Basketball.”

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Cousy with layup for Celtics at Garden vs. Knicks
Bob Cousy in midair with ball against New York Knicks.

attachments.caption:
THE ETERNAL BATTLE, RUSSELL VERSUS CHAMBERLAIN AT BOSTON GARDEN, 1962. Boston Herald-Traveler Photo Morgue, BPL Print Department. 

Celtics legend Bill Russell goes for the block against Philadelphia star Wilt Chamberlain. Appointed Celtics coach in 1966, Russell became the first African American to head a major professional sports team.

element_texts.text: The Eternal Battle, Russell versus Chamberlain at Boston Garden
1 photographic print : gelatin silver ; 9 x 13 1/2 in.
"Russell tries to block Chamberlain in today's game at Boston Garden."  is written in blue pen by photographer on verso.  Russell was the star center for the Celtics and Chamberlain for Philadelphia.

page_blocks.text:
The Boston Garden was originally built to host boxing matches, a favorite sport in the 1920s. Seats were arranged to fill out the floor around a central boxing ring. 

Developer and owner Tex Rickard wanted spectators in every seat to see “sweat on the boxers’ brows.”

attachments.caption:
JACK DEMPSEY AND PROMOTER TEX RICKARD, ca. 1928. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Boston Garden developer and owner Tex Rickard, pictured at left with boxing superstar Jack Dempsey, envisioned the Garden as one of six similar arenas around the country.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Jack Dempsey and promoter Tex Rickard
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
SHIRES-SPOHRER BOUT AT THE BOSTON GARDEN, 1930. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

In this photograph, Art Shires, a notoriously pugilistic baseball player turned boxer, takes on Boston Braves catcher Al Spohrer at the Garden. Shires won the match in four rounds.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Shires-Spohrer bout at the Boston Garden
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
FIGHTERS SIGN AT THE BOSTON GARDEN SEATED L-R: ERNIE SCHAFF, JACK SHARKEY, AND JIM MALONEY, 1931. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

 Seated from left to right, boxers Ernie Schaaf, Jack Sharkey, and Jim Maloney sign contracts at the Garden.

element_texts.text: Copyright   Leslie Jones.; This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Fighters sign at Boston Garden.  Seated left-right:  Ernie Schaaf, Jack Sharkey and Jim Maloney
Fighters sit at desk in Boston Garden offices to sign contracts, as  Garden officials look on.

attachments.caption:
AL MCCOY WEIGHS IN WHILE JOE LOUIS LOOKS ON, AT THE BOSTON GARDEN, 1940. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

The Boston Garden welcomed many famous boxers, including Joe Louis in 1940, pictured here looking on as opponent Al McCoy weighed in. Louis would go on to win the bout in six rounds.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Al McCoy weighs in while Joe Louis looks on, at Boston Garden
Members of both boxers' camps and fight officials look on.

page_blocks.text: The "Big Bad" Bruins professional hockey team moved from the Boston Arena to the Garden in its inaugural year. They played their first game on the new ice on November 20, 1928, before a standing-room-only crowd of 16,000 fans.

attachments.caption:
BRUINS GOALIE TINY THOMPSON IN LOCKER ROOM, ca. 1928. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Cecil “Tiny” Thompson, who goal-tended for the Bruins from 1928–1938, won four Vezina Trophies, awarded to the league’s best goalie.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Bruins goalie Tiny Thompson in locker room
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
BRUINS FORM THE LETTER “B” ON THE ICE, BOSTON GARDEN, 1930–31. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

In their first season at their new home, the Bruins won the Stanley Cup.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Bruins form the letter "B" on the ice, Boston Garden, 1930-31
Boston Bruins (Hockey team); Boston Garden (Boston, Mass.)
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
EDDIE SHORE AND ADAMS, BOSTON GARDEN, 1934-35. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

 Hockey player Eddie Shore and team owner Charles F. Adams are shown in Adams’s office at the Garden. Adams owned both the Bruins and the Boston Braves, and—as the horses decorating his office hint—headed the racing syndicate that founded Suffolk Downs.

element_texts.text: Copyright   Leslie Jones.; This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Eddie Shore and Adams, Boston Garden
Eddie Shore and Weston Adams seated in Adams office at the Garden.

attachments.caption:
BRUINS IN LOCKER ROOM AFTER WINNING THE STANLEY CUP, 1939. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

The 1938-39 Boston Bruins pose in the locker room during celebrations following their Stanley Cup win. The team beat the Toronto Maple Leafs in the final, four games to one.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Bruins in locker room after winning the Stanley Cup
Bruins players still in uniform, some holding beer bottles.

page_blocks.text: The Garden hosted hundreds of other non-sporting events as well, including the popular annual Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus, rodeos, concerts, performances, and some of Boston's most important political rallies and events.

attachments.caption:
CIRCUS ELEPHANTS ARRIVE AT BOSTON GARDEN, ca. 1945. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

The circus announced its annual arrival with a parade down Tremont Street, and all performers—human and creature alike—entered the Garden via a long ramp. The ramp had to be pitched at a particularly shallow angle so that the elephants would willingly ascend it.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Circus elephants arrive at Boston Garden
1 negative : film, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
COW GIRLS AT BOSTON GARDEN FOR THE RODEO, 1931. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

The rodeo was also a popular attraction at the Garden from the venue’s early days, bringing its performers—and a bit of the Wild West—to Boston.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Cow girls at Boston Garden for the rodeo
Four women dressed in cowboy garb, backstage at the Garden.

attachments.caption:
JOHN F. KENNEDY, ELECTION EVE RALLY, BOSTON GARDEN, 1960. Massachusetts Political Archive, BPL Print Department. 

John F. Kennedy, flanked by Representative Thomas “Tip” O’Neill and Mayor John F. Collins, speaks at a 1960 presidential rally on the eve of his election. The event drew some 20,000 people, the largest crowd to ever fill the Garden.

element_texts.text: John F. Kennedy, Election Eve Rally, Boston Garden
1 photographic print : gelatin silver ; 7 x 9 in.
JFK makes a point during speech at the Garden, Tip O'Neill sits to left, Mayor John F. Collins in wheelchair to right.

attachments.caption:
MAYOR KEVIN WHITE AT THE BOSTON GARDEN, 1968. Boston Herald-Traveler Photo Morgue, BPL Print Department.

In 1968, Mayor White of Boston introduced James Brown, who performed at the Garden following the assassination of Martin Luther King, Jr., the previous evening.

element_texts.text: Mayor Kevin White at the Boston Garden
White, Kevin H.; Boston Garden (Boston, Mass.)

page_blocks.text:
From 1930 to 1970, horse races were among the most popular and widely attended sporting events nationwide, competing with only baseball for fans’ affections. 

Attendance boomed during the first decade of the track, topping out at a daily average of 18,388 people filling the stands in 1945. In 1946, people wagered a record average of $1,164,240 on each race day.

attachments.caption:
CROWD WATCHES AS HORSES ARE LED TO THE TRACK, SUFFOLK DOWNS, 1939. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

 Horses make their way from the paddock past the clubhouse en route to the track as curious spectators line the path.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Crowd watches as horses are led to the track, Suffolk Downs
Racetracks; Race horses; Jockeys; Sports spectators
1 negative : film, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
BETTERS [SIC] LINE UP AT THE WINDOW, SUFFOLK DOWNS, ca. 1950. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

In the early years of Suffolk Downs, patrons cast specific wagers at separate windows. This photograph of the $2 show window also features the Daily Double chalkboard above, listing the morning line and the race entries for the first and second races.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Bettors line up at the window, Suffolk Downs
Men and women lined up at $2 show window.

attachments.caption:
A PIGEON FINISHES BEHIND GAY CHARMER AND TRIMGROUND DURING RACE AT SUFFOLK DOWNS, 1966. Boston Herald-Traveler Photo Morgue, Print Department. 

Prior to the 1936 racing season, photo finish technology was installed at Suffolk Downs above the grandstand. While the new system helped determine finish order in tight races, it also yielded some surprising results, as seen in this whimsical photograph run in the Boston Herald on April 29, 1966.

element_texts.text: A pigeon finishes behind Gay Charmer and Trimground during race at Suffolk Downs
1 photographic print : gelatin silver ; 10 x 12 in.
Newspaper caption on verso reads, "Flying high, but good for only sixth place, in the second race Thursday at Suffolk Downs is stray pigeon finishing behind Gay Charmer (3) and Trimground (4)."

attachments.caption:
JOCKEY R. WORKMAN ON 'TIME SUPPLY' AFTER WINNING THE 5TH RACE AT SUFFOLK DOWNS, 1936. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department.  

Future Hall of Fame jockey Raymond Workman converses with track officials about his victory aboard horse Time Supply on July 22, 1936.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Jockey R. Workman on Time Supply after winning the fifth race at Suffolk Downs - see racing form
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

page_blocks.text: Home of the popular Massachusetts Handicap, the racetrack has welcomed many hall-of-fame horses, riders, and trainers throughout its more than 70-year history.

attachments.caption:
JOCKEYS C. AND IRA HANFORD, 1935. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department.  

Nebraska-born brothers Carl and Ira Hanford both rode in the opening meet at Suffolk Downs in July 1935. Carl triumphed in the first race run at the new track aboard horse Eddie Wrack. Ira would go on to ride legendary horse Seabiscuit three times and win the 1936 Kentucky Derby atop Bold Venture.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
SMOOTHING THE COURSE WITH TEAM OF HORSES, SUFFOLK DOWNS, 1942. Boston Herald-Traveler Photo Morgue, BPL Print Department.  

During World War II, gas rationing forced the track to use workhorses rather than tractors to groom the dirt surface. The team could cover the mile oval in twenty minutes.

element_texts.text: Smoothing the course with team of horses, Suffolk Downs
1 photographic print : gelatin silver ; 7 x 9 in.

Newspaper caption on verso reads, "Speaking of Gas Rationing: Those gas driven tractors that formerly hauled the triangle-shaped tractors around the Suffolk Downs oval disappeared yesterday and will remain under cover until gas rationing ends.  In their place reappeared the old reliable work horses, forgotten of recent years but now very, very useful.  Two matched teams, pressed into service between races cover the mile oval in 20 minutes.  They started their slow but necessary plodding yesterday, as shown above."

attachments.caption:
PATRONS TAKE COVER WHEN AIR RAID SIRENS ARE TESTED, SUFFOLK DOWNS, 1942. Boston Herald-Traveler Photo Morgue, Print Department. 

 While Suffolk Downs remained open during World War II, the war’s long shadow touched the racetrack in numerous ways. In July 1942, only empty seats remained on the clubhouse apron as fans participated in an air raid drill, taking cover inside while the siren wailed. The track also held a series of charity events for war relief, including an eight-day meet in 1943 that raised over $635,000 for the War Relief Fund.

element_texts.text: Patrons take cover when air raid sirens are tested, Suffolk Downs
1 photographic print : gelatin silver ; 8 x 10 in.

Printed caption on verso reads, "The clubhouse patrons at Suffolk Downs willingly moved under cover at the first sounding of the air raid siren on Thursday afternoon.  Here are the empty seats as the fans moved in under the protecting ceilings.  Complete cooperation by those present made the alert a distinct success at the track."
Sports: Horse Racing: Tracks: Suffolk Downs

attachments.caption:
THOROUGHBREDS COOLED OUT BY STABLE HANDS AFTER MORNING WORKOUT AT SUFFOLK DOWNS, 1950. Boston Herald-Traveler Photo Morgue, BPL Print Department.

In this early-morning scene at the East Boston track, grooms walk the horses to cool them down after the thoroughbreds have been through their morning workout.

element_texts.text: Thoroughbreds cooled out by stable hands after morning workout at Suffolk Downs
1 photographic print : gelatin silver ; 8 x 10 in.

Newspaper caption on verso reads, "Walking Hots at Suffolk Downs, and this is an early-morning scene at the East Boston track as stable-hand cool out the horses after the thoroughbreds have been through a morning workout.  The horses are never brought right into their stalls after a workout, but are walked until they gradually relax."
Sports: Horse Racing: Tracks: Suffolk Downs

page_blocks.text: Suffolk Downs underwent major renovations in the 1960s, significantly changing the look of its facilities. During the renovations, a glass enclosure covered both the grandstand and refurbished clubhouse, with a new entrance constructed in a dramatic color scheme. The track was further enhanced by a new paddock, half-mile harness oval, and walking ring.

attachments.caption:
NEW MAIN ENTRANCE AND CLUBHOUSE AT SUFFOLK DOWNS, 1962. Boston Herald-Traveler Photo Morgue, BPL Print Department. 

Scaffolding covers the clubhouse entrance during its dramatic remodeling.

element_texts.text: New main entrance and clubhouse at Suffolk Downs
1 photographic print : gelatin silver ; 8 x 10 in.
Scaffolding erected in entrance to clubhouse during remodeling.
Sports: Horse Racing: Tracks: Suffolk Downs

attachments.caption: TROTTERS IN PRE-POST PARADE AT SUFFOLK DOWNS, 1962. Boston Herald-Traveler Photo Morgue, Print Department.

element_texts.text: Trotters in pre-post parade at Suffolk Downs
1 photographic print : gelatin silver ; 8 x 10 in.
Trotters exercising on the track before the start of the racing day.
Sports: Horse Racing: Tracks: Suffolk Downs

attachments.caption:
BILL VEECK AT SUFFOLK DOWNS IN THE WINTER, 1969. Boston Herald-Traveler Photo Morgue, BPL Print Department. 

In 1968, long-time baseball team owner Bill Veeck tried his hand at racetrack management and took over the presidency of Suffolk Downs for a two-year period.

element_texts.text: Bill Veeck at Suffolk Downs in the winter
1 photographic print : gelatin silver ; 8 x 10 in.
Newspaper caption on verso reads, "Bubbling Bill Veeck, president of Suffolk Downs, ignores piles of snow to tell about spring and summer horse racing plans."

attachments.caption:
MINI-SKIRTED MUTUELS MESSENGERS AT SUFFOLK DOWNS, 1969. Boston Herald-Traveler Photo Morgue, BPL Print Department. 

Track president Bill Veeck brought a number of new innovations to Suffolk Downs, including mini-skirted mutuels messengers.

element_texts.text: Mini-skirted mutuels messengers at Suffolk Downs
1 photographic print : gelatin silver ; 8 x 10 in.
Newspaper caption on verso reads, "Bill Veeck, President of Suffolk Downs, has come up with another first in New England racing - mini-skirted mutuels messengers."

page_blocks.text: Many famous faces—and muzzles—have visited Suffolk Downs over the decades. Celebrity guests have included film stars, politicians, musicians, and sports heroes.

attachments.caption:
JIM BRADDOCK WITH JOCKEY I. HANFORD AT SUFFOLK DOWNS, 1935. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department. 

Noted boxer Jim “Cinderella Man” Braddock shakes hands with jockey Ira Hanford before a race.

element_texts.text: This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Jim Braddock with jockey J. Hanford at Suffolk Downs
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
JIM BRADDOCK AND WALLY BERGER, 1935. Leslie Jones Collection, BPL Print Department.  

Wally Berger, star slugger for the Boston Braves baseball team, visits with boxer Jim Braddock in front of the Suffolk Downs clubhouse.

element_texts.text: Copyright   Leslie Jones.; This work is licensed for use under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives License.
Jim Braddock and Wally Berger at Suffolk Downs
1 negative : glass, black & white ; 4 x 5 in.

attachments.caption:
RIN TIN TIN VISITS BORA AT SUFFOLK DOWNS, 1956. Boston Herald-Traveler Photo Morgue, Print Department.  

Movie star Rin Tin Tin stops in for an October 1956 photo op with an equine friend before returning to the Boston Garden, where the famous dog was starring in a rodeo.

element_texts.text: Rin Tin Tin visits Bora at Suffolk Downs
1 photographic print : gelatin silver ; 8 x 10 in.

Newspaper caption on verso reads, "Welcome Visitor at Suffolk Downs was Rin Tin Tin, movie wonder dog, who gets acquainted with Brandywine Stable's Bora, one of the top juveniles in tomorrow's renewal of the $25,000 Mayflower Stakes. The dog won't see the race -- he's appearing with the Rodeo at Boston Garden."
Sports: Horse Racing: Tracks: Suffolk Downs

attachments.caption:
THE BEATLES PERFORMING AT SUFFOLK DOWNS, 1966. Boston Herald-Traveler Photo Morgue, BPL Print Department

The Beatles made their final appearance in Boston at Suffolk Downs. On August 18, 1966, the “Fab Four” performed in front of 25,000 screaming fans.

element_texts.text: The Beatles performing at Suffolk Downs
1 photographic print : gelatin silver ; 7 3/4 x 13 in.
The Beatles perform on stage set up on track at Suffolk Downs while crowd watches from clubhouse stands.
